questions.title: Teens' Opinions About Online News
questions.description: Between 2018 and 2019, Common Sense Media researchers surveyed over 2,000 teens from around the United States. We asked them how they felt about issues related to social media and news literacy. What did they say? See if you can guess!

imageMetadata.resources:
2019: Teen News Engagement: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/pdfs/2019_cs-sm_summarytoplines_release.pdf
2018: Social Media, Social Life: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/2018-social-media-social-life-executive-summary-web.pdf

questions.question: The number of teens who said they used social media multiple times a day increased by 36% from 2012 to 2018.
What percentage of teens said that it's important for them to follow the news and current events?
Where do teens report getting their news most frequently, in order of most to least frequent?
Of teens who get news from YouTube, what percent said they usually find it through a recommended or "watch next" video?

questions.title: Now it's your turn.
questions.description: In the following polls, you can share your opinions on these issues. After responding, start a conversation with some classmates or friends. Did you agree or disagree with each statement? Why, or why not?

questions.question: Social media is a good place to stay up to date on the world's news.
Even if something isn't true, it's OK to share it on social media if it's funny or if I like what it says.
Older people are more likely than younger people to fall for hoaxes online.

questions.title: Want to learn more?
questions.description: Many digital citizenship issues don't have clear, right-or-wrong answers. But you can learn more by starting conversations with your classmates and friends. And for more free resources, visit us at commonsense.org/digital-citizenship.
